Hey Colin-

This is great. Congrats. Do you have any description and screen shots (or a
publication with them) for the Prey Capture experiment? Is this the one from
Ken's co-evolution paper? Just curious about that experiment.




Best regards,
Jeff Clune

Digital Evolution Lab, Michigan State University
jclune@...
www.msu.edu/~jclune




> From: Colin <colin.green1@...>
> Reply-To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Date: Thu, 17 Jun 2010 22:50:29 -0000
> To: "neat@yahoogroups.com" <neat@yahoogroups.com>
> Subject: [neat] SharpNEAT 2 Candidate Release
> 
> Status (2010-06-17) - SharpNEAT 2 Candidate Release
> ---------------------------------------------------
> SharpNEAT 2 development has reached candidate release status. This
> is a fully functional release that is made available in order to
> highlight any defects before issuing the code as an official version
> 2.0
> 
> Features:
>    * Parallel execution. Concurrent genome decoding and genome
> evaluation, also concurrent speciation by k-means clustering.
> Implemented using Parallel Extensions (built-in to .Net 4, available
> as a separate library for compiling within Mono).
>    * Support for both NEAT and HyperNEAT/CPPNs.
>    * Generic framework classes with high level of abstraction and
> therefore flexibility and reusability in both NEAT and non-NEAT
> projects.
>    * Flexible XML configuration.
>    * XML IO for genomes and populations.
>    * Problem domains -
>          o Logical XOR.
>          o Binary 3-multiplexer, 6-multiplexer & 11-multiplexer.
>          o Function regression - sin(x), sin(x^2) & multiplication
> (with visualization).
>          o Boxes Visual Discrimination (with visualization). (see
> http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/publications/2009/stanley.alife09.html)
>          o Prey Capture (with visualization).
>          o Single Pole Balancing
>          o Double Pole Balancing (and variants)
> 
>    * Speciation by k-means clustering (Single thread and parallel
> versions). To my knowledge this is the first NEAT implementation to
> use this approach and as such this code is experimental. Results so
> far have been positive.
>    * Complexity Regulation (previously known as phased pruning).
>    * GUI for modifying experiment parameters, controlling the
> execution of the evolution algorithm and visualization of genomes and
> problem domains.
> 
> 
> Cheers,
> 
> Colin
>
